elements.content: Two robust metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), {H4[Ni­(π-H2O)2]2[Ni­(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}­[VIVW12O40]2·24H2O (1) and {H­[Ni­(π-O)2]2[Ni­(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}­[VIVW10VV 2O40V2]­[VIVW9VV 3O40VIV 2]·24H2O (2) (Tri = 1,2,4-triazole), composed of polyoxometalates (POMs) and metal–organic units, were designed and synthesized by a hydrothermal method. Structure analysis indicates that there is a metal–organic crown [{Ni3(Tri)6(H2O)4}4] ({Ni 12 }) in these two compounds. In 1, the {Ni 12 } crown embraces four pendant Tri ligands that could capture a cationic [Ni­(H2O)2]2+ group, resulting in the Ni13-Tri building unit [Ni­(H2O)2{Ni3(Tri)6(H2O)4}4] ({Ni 13 }). The {Ni 13 } building unit was fused together by Tri bridges into the 2D metal–organic layers, which are pillared by a typical Keggin-type POM [VW12O40]4– to construct a 3D supramolecular framework via the hydrogen bonds. Interestingly, the 2D metal–organic layer in 1 was successfully transferred into a 3D covalent MOF via extension of the length of the pillars by capping a Keggin-type POM with V–O units. Moreover, electrochemical behaviors and electrocatalytic properties of these two compounds were both studied, which can act as bifunctional electrocatalysts toward the reduction of H2O2 and oxidation of nitrite in neutral aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: Two robust metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), {H4[Ni(π-H2O)2]2[Ni(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}[VIVW12O40]2⋅24H2O (1) and {H[Ni(π-O)2]2[Ni(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}[VIVW10VV 2O40V2][VIVW9VV 3O40VIV 2]⋅24H2O (2) (Tri = 1,2,4-triazole), composed of polyoxometalates (POMs) and metal-organic units, were designed and synthesized by a hydrothermal method. Structure analysis indicates that there is a metal-organic crown [{Ni3(Tri)6(H2O)4}4] ({Ni  12  }) in these two compounds. In 1, the {Ni  12  } crown embraces four pendant Tri ligands that could capture a cationic [Ni(H2O)2]2+ group, resulting in the Ni13-Tri building unit [Ni(H2O)2{Ni3(Tri)6(H2O)4}4] ({Ni  13  }). The {Ni  13  } building unit was fused together by Tri bridges into the 2D metal-organic layers, which are pillared by a typical Keggin-type POM [VW12O40]4- to construct a 3D supramolecular framework via the hydrogen bonds. Interestingly, the 2D metal-organic layer in 1 was successfully transferred into a 3D covalent MOF via extension of the length of the pillars by capping a Keggin-type POM with V-O units. Moreover, electrochemical behaviors and electrocatalytic properties of these two compounds were both studied, which can act as bifunctional electrocatalysts toward the reduction of H2O2 and oxidation of nitrite in neutral aqueous solution.

elements.content: An efficient and promising method was explored by utilizing a capping polyoxometalate to bridge 2D metal−organic layers for the construction of highly stable frameworks. In these frameworks, the metal−organic crown [{Ni3(tri)6(H2O)4}4], acting as a functional unit to capture [Ni­(H2O)2]2+ with substitutable sites, plays an important role in the transformation of a 3D supramolecular framework into a covalent framework. Compounds 1 and 2 can both act as bifunctional electrocatalysts toward the reduction of H2O2 and oxidation of nitrite in neutral aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: An efficient and promising method was explored by utilizing a capping polyoxometalate to bridge 2D metal-organic layers for the construction of highly stable frameworks. In these frameworks, the metal-organic crown [{Ni3(tri)6(H2O)4}4], acting as a functional unit to capture [Ni(H2O)2]2+ with substitutable sites, plays an important role in the transformation of a 3D supramolecular framework into a covalent framework. Compounds 1 and 2 can both act as bifunctional electrocatalysts toward the reduction of H2O2 and oxidation of nitrite in neutral aqueous solution.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have developed greatly in the past 20 years, as they possess various potential functions in fluorescence, magnetism, catalysis, proton conduction, gas storage and separation, etc. In this field, multiple methods were proposed to synthesize and functionalize MOFs by changing/decorating organic linkers and inorganic metal cation/cluster based nodes. One significant trend for synthesizing functional MOFs is introducing functional units into the porous materials to evolve composites from a single architecture to multifunctional materials. POMs are a typical class of metal–oxygen clusters with a wide range of components, sizes, and structures. They have been widely used as secondary building units due to their high thermal stability and versatility to build POM-based MOFs. Introducing POMs into MOFs can introduce their advantages into the porous framework materials and greatly improve the stability of the MOF materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have developed greatly in the past 20 years, as they possess various potential functions in fluorescence, magnetism, catalysis, proton conduction, gas storage and separation, etc. In this field, multiple methods were proposed to synthesize and functionalize MOFs by changing/decorating organic linkers and inorganic metal cation/cluster based nodes. One significant trend for synthesizing functional MOFs is introducing functional units into the porous materials to evolve composites from a single architecture to multifunctional materials. POMs are a typical class of metal-oxygen clusters with a wide range of components, sizes, and structures. They have been widely used as secondary building units due to their high thermal stability and versatility to build POM-based MOFs. Introducing POMs into MOFs can introduce their advantages into the porous framework materials and greatly improve the stability of the MOF materials.

elements.content: Recently, the exploration of POM-based MOFs has attracted more and more attention, and numerous POM-based frameworks have been designed and synthesized. These materials can be divided into two classes. (a) POMs are used as guest molecules to functionalize the MOFs. In this field, saturated POMs were usually used as guest molecules to functionalize the MOFs. For examples, Naruke and Liu et al. used Keggin POMs as guest molecules to induce Cu2+ to coordinate with BTC ligands, resulting in a POM-based open framework; recently, a transition-metal-substituted POM was also successfully introduced into POM-based MOF materials. (b) POMs are used as ideally secondary building units through covalent interactions to construct POM-based MOFs. In this field, POMs with high negative charges and abundant surface oxygen atoms that could coordinate with the cationic metal centers represent promising linking nodes between metal cations and organic species for constructing POM-based MOFs. To date, great achievements have been made by introducing metal cations (transition metal and/or Ln cations) into a mixed system of organic ligands and POMs. Although POMs have been regarded as a huge family of isolated nanometric metal oxygen clusters, it is difficult to directly coordinate them with organic bridging ligands to form extended-framework materials. Transition-metal-capped POMs, where each transition-metal center was firmly caught by three to five surface oxygen atoms of the POMs, can serve as nodes to directly coordinate with organic bridging ligands to form stable architectures. In this field, only several zinc-capped POMs were explored for constructing stable 3D architectures. For examples, Dolbecq and co-workers used Zn-capped ε-Keggin POMs to coordinate with benzenedicarboxylic acid ligands to synthesize POM-based MOFs. Lan, Li, et al. connected Zn-capped ε-Keggin POMs with organic ligands, giving rise to stable 3D open frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Recently, the exploration of POM-based MOFs has attracted more and more attention, and numerous POM-based frameworks have been designed and synthesized. These materials can be divided into two classes. (a) POMs are used as guest molecules to functionalize the MOFs. In this field, saturated POMs were usually used as guest molecules to functionalize the MOFs. For examples, Naruke and Liu et al. used Keggin POMs as guest molecules to induce Cu2+ to coordinate with BTC ligands, resulting in a POM-based open framework; recently, a transition-metal-substituted POM was also successfully introduced into POM-based MOF materials. (b) POMs are used as ideally secondary building units through covalent interactions to construct POM-based MOFs. In this field, POMs with high negative charges and abundant surface oxygen atoms that could coordinate with the cationic metal centers represent promising linking nodes between metal cations and organic species for constructing POM-based MOFs. To date, great achievements have been made by introducing metal cations (transition metal and/or Ln cations) into a mixed system of organic ligands and POMs. Although POMs have been regarded as a huge family of isolated nanometric metal oxygen clusters, it is difficult to directly coordinate them with organic bridging ligands to form extended-framework materials. Transition-metal-capped POMs, where each transition-metal center was firmly caught by three to five surface oxygen atoms of the POMs, can serve as nodes to directly coordinate with organic bridging ligands to form stable architectures. In this field, only several zinc-capped POMs were explored for constructing stable 3D architectures. For examples, Dolbecq and co-workers used Zn-capped ε-Keggin POMs to coordinate with benzenedicarboxylic acid ligands to synthesize POM-based MOFs. Lan, Li, et al. connected Zn-capped ε-Keggin POMs with organic ligands, giving rise to stable 3D open frameworks.

elements.content: As is well-known, vanadium can exist in multiple oxidation states (V5+, V4+, and V3+) and coordination geometries (VO4 tetrahedra, VO5 square pyramids, and VO6 octahedra). The versatile vanadium ion tends to form mixed-valence states in the self-assembly process. Presently, monocapped, dicapped, tricapped, tetracapped, and hexacapped POMs have beem synthesized, which could supply versatile building units for constructing stable MOFs. In addition, the V-capped POMs are more stable than Zn-capped POMs due to the existence of high-valence vanadium centers, which are usually capped on the surface of the POMs with four or five V–O bonds. Accordingly, it will be more conducive to build stable MOFs with vanadium-capped POMs as the nodes. However, they have rarely been studied due to the inert terminal oxygen atoms of VO. In this field, we have obtained the series of bicapped and tetracapped polyoxoanions [VW12O40(VO)2], [(VMo8V4O40)­(VO)2], [(VMo8V4O40)­(VO)4], [AsNb9V3O40(VO)4], and [AsNb8V4O40(VO)4]. These bicapped and tetracapped POMs could coordinate with two or four transition-metal cations via the V–O units, resulting in a series of functional materials. However, only a few low-dimensional hybrid materials, such as a dumbbell-like dimer, a 1D chain, and a 2D layer, have been obtained to date, by the use of simple metal–organic units to connect the V-capped polyoxoanions. In this study, the 3D supramolecular framework {H4[Ni­(π-H2O)2]2[Ni­(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}­[VIVW12O40]2·24H2O (1), consisting of metal–organic layers pillared by typical Keggin POMs {VW12O40}, were designed and synthesized. The 3D supramolecular framework was further transferred into the covalent 3D framework {H­[Ni­(π-O)2]2[Ni­(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}­[VIVW10VIV 2O40VV 2]­[VIVW9VIV 3O40VV 2]·24H2O (2), via replacment of a Keggin anion {VW12O40} with vanadium-bicapped POMs. Compound 2 represents the first 3D MOF with divanadium-capped POMs as the nodes. Compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit high chemical stability and can act as bifunctional electrocatalysts for the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and oxidation of nitrite in a neutral aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: As is well-known, vanadium can exist in multiple oxidation states (V5+, V4+, and V3+) and coordination geometries (VO4 tetrahedra, VO5 square pyramids, and VO6 octahedra). The versatile vanadium ion tends to form mixed-valence states in the self-assembly process. Presently, monocapped, dicapped, tricapped, tetracapped, and hexacapped POMs have beem synthesized, which could supply versatile building units for constructing stable MOFs. In addition, the V-capped POMs are more stable than Zn-capped POMs due to the existence of high-valence vanadium centers, which are usually capped on the surface of the POMs with four or five V-O bonds. Accordingly, it will be more conducive to build stable MOFs with vanadium-capped POMs as the nodes. However, they have rarely been studied due to the inert terminal oxygen atoms of VO. In this field, we have obtained the series of bicapped and tetracapped polyoxoanions [VW12O40(VO)2], [(VMo8V4O40)(VO)2], [(VMo8V4O40)(VO)4], [AsNb9V3O40(VO)4], and [AsNb8V4O40(VO)4]. These bicapped and tetracapped POMs could coordinate with two or four transition-metal cations via the V-O units, resulting in a series of functional materials. However, only a few low-dimensional hybrid materials, such as a dumbbell-like dimer, a 1D chain, and a 2D layer, have been obtained to date, by the use of simple metal-organic units to connect the V-capped polyoxoanions. In this study, the 3D supramolecular framework {H4[Ni(π-H2O)2]2[Ni(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}[VIVW12O40]2⋅24H2O (1), consisting of metal-organic layers pillared by typical Keggin POMs {VW12O40}, were designed and synthesized. The 3D supramolecular framework was further transferred into the covalent 3D framework {H[Ni(π-O)2]2[Ni(rt-H2O)2]8Ni4(Tri)24}[VIVW10VIV 2O40VV 2][VIVW9VIV 3O40VV 2]⋅24H2O (2), via replacment of a Keggin anion {VW12O40} with vanadium-bicapped POMs. Compound 2 represents the first 3D MOF with divanadium-capped POMs as the nodes. Compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit high chemical stability and can act as bifunctional electrocatalysts for the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and oxidation of nitrite in a neutral aqueous solution.

elements.content: All of the chemical reagents were commercially purchased and directly used. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were determined on an Alpha Centauri FT/IR Sspectrophotometer at wavenumbers between 400 and 4000 cm–1. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out under a flowing N2 atmosphere with a PerkinElmer TGA7 instrument (heating rate 10 °C min–1). The contents of Ni, V, and W were determined by a PLASMA-SPEC (I) inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic emission spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were conducted on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer. Electrochemical and electrocatalytic analysis was performed using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 600E). An Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode and platinum gauze as the counter electrode.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All of the chemical reagents were commercially purchased and directly used. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were determined on an Alpha Centauri FT/IR Sspectrophotometer at wavenumbers between 400 and 4000 cm-1. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out under a flowing N2 atmosphere with a PerkinElmer TGA7 instrument (heating rate 10 °C min-1). The contents of Ni, V, and W were determined by a PLASMA-SPEC (I) inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic emission spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were conducted on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer. Electrochemical and electrocatalytic analysis was performed using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 600E). An Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode and platinum gauze as the counter electrode.

elements.content: A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.05 g, 0.43 mmol), Na2WO4·2H2O (0.2 g, 0.61 mmol), Ni­(Ac)2·4H2O (0.05 g, 0.20 mmol), triazole (0.033 g, 0.48 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of HCl (0.30 mL, 4.0 M) and H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After drying at room temperature, orange crystals were obtained with a yield of ca. 45% (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 1: W, 48.78; V, 1.13; Ni, 9.08. Found: W, 49.12; V, 0.98; Ni, 9.03. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν̃ 1623 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1163 (m), 1051 (m), 947 (s), 874 (s), 773 (s), 664 (s), 615 (s), 467 (s) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.05 g, 0.43 mmol), Na2WO4⋅2H2O (0.2 g, 0.61 mmol), Ni(Ac)2⋅4H2O (0.05 g, 0.20 mmol), triazole (0.033 g, 0.48 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of HCl (0.30 mL, 4.0 M) and H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After drying at room temperature, orange crystals were obtained with a yield of ca. 45% (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 1: W, 48.78; V, 1.13; Ni, 9.08. Found: W, 49.12; V, 0.98; Ni, 9.03. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν̃ 1623 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1163 (m), 1051 (m), 947 (s), 874 (s), 773 (s), 664 (s), 615 (s), 467 (s) cm-1.

elements.content: A similar synthetic process of 1 was adopted for the synthesis of compound 2, except that l-tartaric acid (0.033 g, 0.22 mmol) was used in the synthesis of 2. Black crystals of 2 were isolated in ca. 36% yield (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 2: W, 40.69; V, 6.53; Ni, 9.57. Found: W, 39.74; V, 6.28; Ni, 10.32. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν̃ 1621 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1165 (m), 1081 (m), 948(s), 876 (s), 764 (s), 667 (s), 615(s), 490 (s) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2 

A similar synthetic process of 1 was adopted for the synthesis of compound 2, except that l-tartaric acid (0.033 g, 0.22 mmol) was used in the synthesis of 2. Black crystals of 2 were isolated in ca. 36% yield (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 2: W, 40.69; V, 6.53; Ni, 9.57. Found: W, 39.74; V, 6.28; Ni, 10.32. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν̃ 1621 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1165 (m), 1081 (m), 948(s), 876 (s), 764 (s), 667 (s), 615(s), 490 (s) cm-1.

elements.content: A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.04 g, 0.33 mmol), Na2WO4·2H2O (0.1 g, 0.30 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.015 g, 0.01 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 170 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The brown crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After that, the crystals were dried at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (Hbpy)4(VW12O40)⋅6H2O ({VW12}; bpy = 4,4'-Bipyridine)

A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.04 g, 0.33 mmol), Na2WO4⋅2H2O (0.1 g, 0.30 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.015 g, 0.01 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 170 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The brown crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After that, the crystals were dried at room temperature.

elements.content: The crystal data of 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 293 K. In the collection process, graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with λ = 0.71073 Å was adopted. The structure was resolved by direct methods. The crystal data were refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97 software. During the refinement, “isor”, a restrictive refinement command, was used to restrain some non-hydrogen atoms to eliminate NPD and ADP errors in the data refinement, resulting in the restrictive values of 186 (for 1) and 96 (for 2). In the POM anions of 1 and 2, four oxygen atoms on the central VO4 unit were disordered over eight half-occupied sites, which results in short nonbonding interactions. Further, some short interactions in the range of 2.5–3.0 Å between oxygen atoms and water molecules indicated the existence of H bonds. The H atoms on these O atoms could not be localized from the difference Fourier map because of the limited data quality. Therefore, the hydrogen atoms of H2O were directly added into the formula. As a result, there are some isolated oxygen atoms, and the calculated molecular weight is different from that reported. The hydrogen atoms of Tri were fixed in calculated positions. The refinement results of 1 and 2 are summarized in Table S1, and the crystallographic data in CIF format are available freely from the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre (CCDC). The deposition numbers are CCDC 1580144 and 1580145 for 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The crystal data of 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 293 K. In the collection process, graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with λ = 0.71073 Å was adopted. The structure was resolved by direct methods. The crystal data were refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97 software. During the refinement, "isor", a restrictive refinement command, was used to restrain some non-hydrogen atoms to eliminate NPD and ADP errors in the data refinement, resulting in the restrictive values of 186 (for 1) and 96 (for 2). In the POM anions of 1 and 2, four oxygen atoms on the central VO4 unit were disordered over eight half-occupied sites, which results in short nonbonding interactions. Further, some short interactions in the range of 2.5-3.0 Å between oxygen atoms and water molecules indicated the existence of H bonds. The H atoms on these O atoms could not be localized from the difference Fourier map because of the limited data quality. Therefore, the hydrogen atoms of H2O were directly added into the formula. As a result, there are some isolated oxygen atoms, and the calculated molecular weight is different from that reported. The hydrogen atoms of Tri were fixed in calculated positions. The refinement results of 1 and 2 are summarized in Table S1, and the crystallographic data in CIF format are available freely from the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre (CCDC). The deposition numbers are CCDC 1580144 and 1580145 for 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal structure analysis indicates that compound 1 is composed of 2D metal–organic layers, Keggin-type [VW12O40]4– {VW12} anions (), and lattice water molecules. In the 2D metal–organic layer, three Ni2+ centers were linked by six Tri ligands through a Ni–N–N–Ni mode to form a cationic {Ni3(Tri)6} group (a). In the {Ni3(Tri)6} group, there are two crystallographically independent nickel metal centers (Ni(2) and Ni(3)), which are both in an octahedral coordination environment. As shown in Figure S3a, the Ni(3) ion sits in a twisted-octahedral coordination configuration completed by four N atoms from four Tri ligands and two terminally coordinated water molecules. The Ni(3)–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.052(13)–2.110(13) Å. The Ni(2) center is also adopts a six-coordinated configuration, which was completed by six N atoms from six Tri ligands; the Ni(2)–N distances range from 2.072(12) to 2.138(13) Å. Interestingly, four {Ni3(Tri)6} units were fused together by N atoms of Tri ligands between two adjacent {Ni3(Tri)6} units to form the distorted metal–organic crown [{Ni3(Tri)6(H2O)4}4] ({Ni 12 }) (b). As is well-known, crown-type molecules, such as calixarenes and crown ethers, possess potential applications in molecular recognition and separation. In compound 1, the {Ni 12 } crown embraces four pendant Tri ligands that could capture a cationic [Ni­(H2O)2]2+ (Ni(1)) group in its center with four Ni–N bonds, resulting in the Ni13-Tri building unit {Ni 13 } (d); the Ni(1)–N bond lengths are 2.099(12) Å. Importantly, the [Ni­(H2O)2]2+ group in the center of the {Ni 12 } crown is firmly fixed by four N atoms from four Tri ligands, and two H2O molecules coordinated with the Ni2+ center perpendicular to the Ni–N(4) plane. The coordinated H2O molecules not only can act as H donors to form H bonds with adjacent oxygen atoms but also can be easily replaced by other O or N atoms. Further, the metal–organic crown {Ni 12 } was fused together to form a 2D metal–organic layer though sharing of the {Ni3(Tri)6} units with four neighboring {Ni 12 } crowns.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure

Crystal structure analysis indicates that compound 1 is composed of 2D metal-organic layers, Keggin-type [VW12O40]4- {VW12} anions (), and lattice water molecules. In the 2D metal-organic layer, three Ni2+ centers were linked by six Tri ligands through a Ni-N-N-Ni mode to form a cationic {Ni3(Tri)6} group (a). In the {Ni3(Tri)6} group, there are two crystallographically independent nickel metal centers (Ni(2) and Ni(3)), which are both in an octahedral coordination environment. As shown in Figure S3a, the Ni(3) ion sits in a twisted-octahedral coordination configuration completed by four N atoms from four Tri ligands and two terminally coordinated water molecules. The Ni(3)-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.052(13)-2.110(13) Å. The Ni(2) center is also adopts a six-coordinated configuration, which was completed by six N atoms from six Tri ligands; the Ni(2)-N distances range from 2.072(12) to 2.138(13) Å. Interestingly, four {Ni3(Tri)6} units were fused together by N atoms of Tri ligands between two adjacent {Ni3(Tri)6} units to form the distorted metal-organic crown [{Ni3(Tri)6(H2O)4}4] ({Ni  12  }) (b). As is well-known, crown-type molecules, such as calixarenes and crown ethers, possess potential applications in molecular recognition and separation. In compound 1, the {Ni  12  } crown embraces four pendant Tri ligands that could capture a cationic [Ni(H2O)2]2+ (Ni(1)) group in its center with four Ni-N bonds, resulting in the Ni13-Tri building unit {Ni  13  } (d); the Ni(1)-N bond lengths are 2.099(12) Å. Importantly, the [Ni(H2O)2]2+ group in the center of the {Ni  12  } crown is firmly fixed by four N atoms from four Tri ligands, and two H2O molecules coordinated with the Ni2+ center perpendicular to the Ni-N(4) plane. The coordinated H2O molecules not only can act as H donors to form H bonds with adjacent oxygen atoms but also can be easily replaced by other O or N atoms. Further, the metal-organic crown {Ni  12  } was fused together to form a 2D metal-organic layer though sharing of the {Ni3(Tri)6} units with four neighboring {Ni  12  } crowns.

elements.content: (a) Keggin-type polyoxoanion [VW12O40]4–. (b) Bicapped Keggin-type [VW12O40(VO)2].
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Keggin-type polyoxoanion [VW12O40]4-. (b) Bicapped Keggin-type [VW12O40(VO)2].

elements.content: Ball and stick views of (a) [Ni3(triazole)6(H2O)4]2+], (b) {Ni 12 } metal–organic crown, (c) {Ni 13 } unit, and (d) 2D metal–organic layer in 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  Ball and stick views of (a) [Ni3(triazole)6(H2O)4]2+], (b) {Ni  12  } metal-organic crown, (c) {Ni  13  } unit, and (d) 2D metal-organic layer in 1.

elements.content: In the metal–organic layer, the H2O molecules coordinated with the Ni2+ at the center of the {Ni 12 } crown can act as donor oxygen atoms to form H bonds with the oxygen atoms on the surface of POMs. The typical hydrogen bond distances are O3···O13 = 2.9576 Å and O4···O9 = 2.8814 Å, which are responsible for the formation of the 3D supramolecular network. In this framework, the Keggin-type anion fits tightly into the cavity of the {Ni 12 } crown, as its size and shape are complementary to pillar the metal–organic layers. {VW12} clusters adopt two different molecular orientations in the supramoelcular network, where the {VW12} anions are located at both sides of the metal–organic layer and belong to two different planes with a angle of about 45°.
elements.clean_text: In the metal-organic layer, the H2O molecules coordinated with the Ni2+ at the center of the {Ni  12  } crown can act as donor oxygen atoms to form H bonds with the oxygen atoms on the surface of POMs. The typical hydrogen bond distances are O3⋅⋅⋅O13 = 2.9576 Å and O4⋅⋅⋅O9 = 2.8814 Å, which are responsible for the formation of the 3D supramolecular network. In this framework, the Keggin-type anion fits tightly into the cavity of the {Ni  12  } crown, as its size and shape are complementary to pillar the metal-organic layers. {VW12} clusters adopt two different molecular orientations in the supramoelcular network, where the {VW12} anions are located at both sides of the metal-organic layer and belong to two different planes with a angle of about 45°.

elements.content: As described above, the 2D metal–organic layers are fused together via H bonds between the water molecules on the nickel centers and oxygen atoms on the surface of the POMs ( and Figure S6a) and the electrostatic interactions between the cationic layers and anionic POM clusters. It is obviously observed that these interactions are fairly weak, and the water molecules on the central nickel of the {Ni 12 } crown could be easily replaced by O atoms on the surface of the POMs. However, the Keggin-type anion with a length of 1.0 nm could not coordinate with the nickel center in the metal–organic layer, due to the large steric effect of both the metal–organic crown and spherelike Keggin-type anion. Previous works have demonstrated that capped POMs with metal–O units can further extend the length of the POMs, which could be subsequently used to coordinate with transition-metal cations via oxygen atoms in the metal–O units (). In our previous study, we explored a series of capped POMs, which have been confirmed as efficient building units to coordinate with metal cations and metal–organic units. However, only a dumbbell-like dimer, 1D chain, and 2D layerlike hybrid materials were obtained due to the use of simple metal cations or metal–organic units in the assembly process.
elements.clean_text: As described above, the 2D metal-organic layers are fused together via H bonds between the water molecules on the nickel centers and oxygen atoms on the surface of the POMs ( and Figure S6a) and the electrostatic interactions between the cationic layers and anionic POM clusters. It is obviously observed that these interactions are fairly weak, and the water molecules on the central nickel of the {Ni  12  } crown could be easily replaced by O atoms on the surface of the POMs. However, the Keggin-type anion with a length of 1.0 nm could not coordinate with the nickel center in the metal-organic layer, due to the large steric effect of both the metal-organic crown and spherelike Keggin-type anion. Previous works have demonstrated that capped POMs with metal-O units can further extend the length of the POMs, which could be subsequently used to coordinate with transition-metal cations via oxygen atoms in the metal-O units (). In our previous study, we explored a series of capped POMs, which have been confirmed as efficient building units to coordinate with metal cations and metal-organic units. However, only a dumbbell-like dimer, 1D chain, and 2D layerlike hybrid materials were obtained due to the use of simple metal cations or metal-organic units in the assembly process.

elements.content: (a) Ball and stick and polyhedral representation of the 3D supramolecular structure of 1 along the b c plane. (b) Arrangement of the POM and {Ni 13 } crown, with the larger red atoms representing water molecules. (c) Ball and stick and polyhedral representation of the POM and metal–organic layer along the ab plane. (d) Hydrogen bonds between the Keggin anion and water molecules on the metal–organic layer.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Ball and stick and polyhedral representation of the 3D supramolecular structure of 1 along the b c plane. (b) Arrangement of the POM and {Ni  13  } crown, with the larger red atoms representing water molecules. (c) Ball and stick and polyhedral representation of the POM and metal-organic layer along the ab plane. (d) Hydrogen bonds between the Keggin anion and water molecules on the metal-organic layer.

elements.content: In compound 2, 2D metal–organic layers in the supramolecular framework of 1 were successfully transferred into a covalent 3D MOF via extension of the length of POM pillars by capping a Keggin-type POM with two V–O units. The oxygen atoms in the V–O units replaced the water molecules on the nickel centers to form a covalent 3D framework. The two capping vanadium atoms are both fixed by four oxygen atoms on the {W4O4} faces (). The terminal oxygen atom of the VO unit was further used to connect Ni2+ ions in the metal–organic layer to form a covalent 3D framework ( and Figure S6b). The V–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.58(3)1.934(11) Å, and the Ni(1)–O(10) and Ni(1)–O(12) bond lengths are 2.07(3) and 2.03(3) Å, respectively. In the synthesis of 2, l-tartaric acid, a weak acid, was used as the modulator to adjust the pH. The transition-metal-substituted POMs [VW10V2O40(VO)2]2– and [VW9V3O40 (VO)2]3– capped by two VO units were obtained at a lower pH for the similar reaction system of 1.
elements.clean_text: In compound 2, 2D metal-organic layers in the supramolecular framework of 1 were successfully transferred into a covalent 3D MOF via extension of the length of POM pillars by capping a Keggin-type POM with two V-O units. The oxygen atoms in the V-O units replaced the water molecules on the nickel centers to form a covalent 3D framework. The two capping vanadium atoms are both fixed by four oxygen atoms on the {W4O4} faces (). The terminal oxygen atom of the VO unit was further used to connect Ni2+ ions in the metal-organic layer to form a covalent 3D framework ( and Figure S6b). The V-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.58(3)1.934(11) Å, and the Ni(1)-O(10) and Ni(1)-O(12) bond lengths are 2.07(3) and 2.03(3) Å, respectively. In the synthesis of 2, l-tartaric acid, a weak acid, was used as the modulator to adjust the pH. The transition-metal-substituted POMs [VW10V2O40(VO)2]2- and [VW9V3O40 (VO)2]3- capped by two VO units were obtained at a lower pH for the similar reaction system of 1.

elements.content: (a) Ball and stick and polyhedral representation of the 3D covalent framework along the bc plane in 2. (b) Arrangement of the POM and {Ni 13 } crown in 2.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Ball and stick and polyhedral representation of the 3D covalent framework along the bc plane in 2. (b) Arrangement of the POM and {Ni  13  } crown in 2.

elements.content: Valence sum calculations confirm that the capping V centers are in the oxidation state +IV and all the Ni and W atoms are in +II and +VI oxidation states, respectively. In the POM anions of 1 and 2, the four oxygen atoms on the central VO4 unit are disordered over eight half-occupied positions, which is usually observed in Keggin clusters. To further confirm the valence state of the V centers, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted with compounds 1 and 2 (). The XPS spectrum of 1 gives a binding energy of 516.4 eV for V­(IV) 2p3/2, revealing that the central V heteroatom is in the +IV oxidation state. For 2, one intense unsymmetrical V 2p3/2 peak indicates the mixed valence of V in 2. Integration of the V­(V) 2p3/2 peak and the V­(IV) 2p3/2 peak with V satellite peaks (517.3 and 515.9 eV) gives the calculated V­(V) and V­(IV) ratio as ∼5:6, and the content of V in 2 was further confirmed by the ICP results. Accordingly, the capping V center and V heteroatom in compound 2 are all in the +IV oxidation state, and the others are in the +V oxidation state.
elements.clean_text: Valence sum calculations confirm that the capping V centers are in the oxidation state +IV and all the Ni and W atoms are in +II and +VI oxidation states, respectively. In the POM anions of 1 and 2, the four oxygen atoms on the central VO4 unit are disordered over eight half-occupied positions, which is usually observed in Keggin clusters. To further confirm the valence state of the V centers, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted with compounds 1 and 2 (). The XPS spectrum of 1 gives a binding energy of 516.4 eV for V(IV) 2p3/2, revealing that the central V heteroatom is in the +IV oxidation state. For 2, one intense unsymmetrical V 2p3/2 peak indicates the mixed valence of V in 2. Integration of the V(V) 2p3/2 peak and the V(IV) 2p3/2 peak with V satellite peaks (517.3 and 515.9 eV) gives the calculated V(V) and V(IV) ratio as ~5:6, and the content of V in 2 was further confirmed by the ICP results. Accordingly, the capping V center and V heteroatom in compound 2 are all in the +IV oxidation state, and the others are in the +V oxidation state.

elements.content: XPS spectra of the V 2p level of (a) 1 and (b) 2.
elements.clean_text: 5  XPS spectra of the V 2p level of (a) 1 and (b) 2.

elements.content: As is well-known, POMs usually exhibit interesting electrochemical properties and have been widely used for electrocatalytic redox reactions, as they can experience rapid reversible and stepwise multielectron-transfer processes while retaining the structural integrity. Electrochemical studies with 1- and 2-decorated carbon paste electrodes (1- and 2-CPEs) were performed in 0.2 M pH 7.0 Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 buffer solution (a,b). In the cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves of 1, three pairs of redox peaks are observed in the potential range of −600 to +800 mV with the mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2 of 186 (I–I′), −126 (II–II′), and −286 mV (III–III′) at a scan rate of 40 mV s–1. The peaks II–II′ and III–III′ can be ascribed to the redox process of W centers in the anion cluster. The peaks of I–I′ can be ascribed to the redox peaks of the vanadium center in 1. In the CV curve of 2, four pairs of redox peaks are observed in the potential range of −600 to +500 mV with the mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2 of 406 (I–I′), 156 (II–II′), −23 (III–III′), and −291 mV (IV–IV′) at a scan rate of 40 mV s–1. The peaks I–I′ and II–II′ are attributed to the V centers in the POM framework, and the peaks III–III′ and IV–IV′ are related to the redox processes of W centers. Furthermore, the peak potentials changed gradually with scan rates varying from 40 to 200 mV s–1, where the reductive potentials of cathodic peaks shift negatively and the oxidation peak potentials shift positively at the same time. In addition, the peak current densities are proportional to the scan rates up to 200 mV s–1 (Figure S11), which demonstrates a surface-controlled redox process of 1-CPE and 2-CPE.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Properties

As is well-known, POMs usually exhibit interesting electrochemical properties and have been widely used for electrocatalytic redox reactions, as they can experience rapid reversible and stepwise multielectron-transfer processes while retaining the structural integrity. Electrochemical studies with 1- and 2-decorated carbon paste electrodes (1- and 2-CPEs) were performed in 0.2 M pH 7.0 Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 buffer solution (a,b). In the cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves of 1, three pairs of redox peaks are observed in the potential range of -600 to +800 mV with the mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2 of 186 (I-I'), -126 (II-II'), and -286 mV (III-III') at a scan rate of 40 mV s-1. The peaks II-II' and III-III' can be ascribed to the redox process of W centers in the anion cluster. The peaks of I-I' can be ascribed to the redox peaks of the vanadium center in 1. In the CV curve of 2, four pairs of redox peaks are observed in the potential range of -600 to +500 mV with the mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2 of 406 (I-I'), 156 (II-II'), -23 (III-III'), and -291 mV (IV-IV') at a scan rate of 40 mV s-1. The peaks I-I' and II-II' are attributed to the V centers in the POM framework, and the peaks III-III' and IV-IV' are related to the redox processes of W centers. Furthermore, the peak potentials changed gradually with scan rates varying from 40 to 200 mV s-1, where the reductive potentials of cathodic peaks shift negatively and the oxidation peak potentials shift positively at the same time. In addition, the peak current densities are proportional to the scan rates up to 200 mV s-1 (Figure S11), which demonstrates a surface-controlled redox process of 1-CPE and 2-CPE.

elements.content: CVs of (a) 1-CPE and (b) 2-CPE in pH 7.0 Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 (0.2 M) buffer solution with different scan rates from 40 to 200 mV s–1. Electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2 by (c) 1-CPE and (d) 2-CPE in pH 7.0 Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 (0.2 M) buffer solution. Electrocatalytic oxidation of NO2 – by (e) 1-CPE and (f) 2-CPE in pH 7.0 (0.2 M)­Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 buffer solution. Scan rate: 75 mV s–1.
elements.clean_text: 6  CVs of (a) 1-CPE and (b) 2-CPE in pH 7.0 Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 (0.2 M) buffer solution with different scan rates from 40 to 200 mV s-1. Electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2 by (c) 1-CPE and (d) 2-CPE in pH 7.0 Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 (0.2 M) buffer solution. Electrocatalytic oxidation of NO2 - by (e) 1-CPE and (f) 2-CPE in pH 7.0 (0.2 M)Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 buffer solution. Scan rate: 75 mV s-1.

elements.content: Hydrogen peroxide and nitrite are both widespread in the food industry. The exploration of electrocatalysts to detect and eliminate these hazardous materials has attracted extensive attention. In this work, the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2 with 1- and 2-CPEs in a neutral Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 buffer solution was studied. As is well-known, the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2 usually demands a large overpotential; at a bare CPE, there is no obvious response for H2O2 in this buffer solution. For 1- and 2-CPEs, the reduction peak currents (II–II′ and III–III′ for 1-CPE, III–III′ and IV–IV′ for 2-CPE) increase markedly with addition of H2O2 to the neutral aqueous solution, while the corresponding oxidation peak currents dramatically decreased. These results reveal that the reduced species of 1- and 2-CPEs are both active for the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2.
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen peroxide and nitrite are both widespread in the food industry. The exploration of electrocatalysts to detect and eliminate these hazardous materials has attracted extensive attention. In this work, the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2 with 1- and 2-CPEs in a neutral Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 buffer solution was studied. As is well-known, the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2 usually demands a large overpotential; at a bare CPE, there is no obvious response for H2O2 in this buffer solution. For 1- and 2-CPEs, the reduction peak currents (II-II' and III-III' for 1-CPE, III-III' and IV-IV' for 2-CPE) increase markedly with addition of H2O2 to the neutral aqueous solution, while the corresponding oxidation peak currents dramatically decreased. These results reveal that the reduced species of 1- and 2-CPEs are both active for the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2.

elements.content: Very interestingly, it was found that 1-CPE and 2-CPE are highly active toward the electrocatalytic oxidation of nitrite in natural aqueous solution. As shown in e,f, it can be clearly observed that a sharp increase in the oxidation peak current of 1- and 2-CPEs was detected with the addition of nitrite, indicating that 1-CPE and 2-CPE both show excellent activity toward the electrocatalytic oxidation of nitrite in 0.2 M pH 7.0 Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 buffer solution. These are the first examples of V-capped POM-based MOF materials which have been explored as excellent electrocatalysts for the oxidation of nitrite in a natural aqueous solution. Further, the relationship of peak current and concentration of H2O2 or NO2 – is linear at concentrations lower than 20 mM, which could be used to quantitatively determinate the content of H2O2 and nitrite in the neutral aqueous solution (Figure S12). For a comparison of the electraocatalytic activity between POM and POM-based MOFs, we tried to isolate {VW12O40} anions with only organic ligands in the absence of metal cations to avoid the influence of Ni2+ centers. After a great number of parallel experiments, the non-water-soluble inorganic–organic hybrid material (Hbpy)4(VW12O40)·6H2O ({VW 12 }, bpy = 4,4-bipyridine) was isolated. In 2009, the [VW12O40] anion was synthesized by Niu et al. with bpy ligands in the presence of Mn2+ cations, molybdenum powder, and MoO3 in the reaction system, although the Mn2+ cations, molybdenum powder, and MoO3 did not exist in the final product. Further, they also isolated a [ZnW12O40]6– anion with bpy ligands, where a ZnO4 tetrahedral sites is in the center of the Keggin anion. It could be found that the catalytic currents of {VW 12 } toward nitrite were much smaller than those of 1- and 2-CPEs (Figure S13).
elements.clean_text: Very interestingly, it was found that 1-CPE and 2-CPE are highly active toward the electrocatalytic oxidation of nitrite in natural aqueous solution. As shown in e,f, it can be clearly observed that a sharp increase in the oxidation peak current of 1- and 2-CPEs was detected with the addition of nitrite, indicating that 1-CPE and 2-CPE both show excellent activity toward the electrocatalytic oxidation of nitrite in 0.2 M pH 7.0 Na2HPO4-NaH2PO4 buffer solution. These are the first examples of V-capped POM-based MOF materials which have been explored as excellent electrocatalysts for the oxidation of nitrite in a natural aqueous solution. Further, the relationship of peak current and concentration of H2O2 or NO2 - is linear at concentrations lower than 20 mM, which could be used to quantitatively determinate the content of H2O2 and nitrite in the neutral aqueous solution (Figure S12). For a comparison of the electraocatalytic activity between POM and POM-based MOFs, we tried to isolate {VW12O40} anions with only organic ligands in the absence of metal cations to avoid the influence of Ni2+ centers. After a great number of parallel experiments, the non-water-soluble inorganic-organic hybrid material (Hbpy)4(VW12O40)⋅6H2O ({VW  12  }, bpy = 4,4-bipyridine) was isolated. In 2009, the [VW12O40] anion was synthesized by Niu et al. with bpy ligands in the presence of Mn2+ cations, molybdenum powder, and MoO3 in the reaction system, although the Mn2+ cations, molybdenum powder, and MoO3 did not exist in the final product. Further, they also isolated a [ZnW12O40]6- anion with bpy ligands, where a ZnO4 tetrahedral sites is in the center of the Keggin anion. It could be found that the catalytic currents of {VW  12  } toward nitrite were much smaller than those of 1- and 2-CPEs (Figure S13).

elements.content: The design and synthesis of stable catalysts have been constantly pursued in industrial applications. The stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 were studied in aqueous solution with a wide pH range of 1–12. In a typical process, 100 mg of crystals of compounds 1 and 2 was soaked in sodium hydroxide and sulfuric acid aqueous solutions with pH 1, 4, 7, 9, and 12 for 24 h, respectively. Then, the crystals were filtered, washed, and dried at room temperature. XRD analysis reveals that the host frameworks of 1 and 2 were retained after doping in the pH 1–12 aqueous solutions for 24 h, confirming that compounds 1 and 2 are stable in pH 1–12 aqueous solutions (). However, the block crystal of 1 became a powder when it was soaked in pH 12 aqueous solutions for 24 h, whereas compound 2 remained as dark black block crystals. These results confirm that the stability of 3D supramolecular framework was much enhanced when it was transferred into a covalent 3D framework.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Study

The design and synthesis of stable catalysts have been constantly pursued in industrial applications. The stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 were studied in aqueous solution with a wide pH range of 1-12. In a typical process, 100 mg of crystals of compounds 1 and 2 was soaked in sodium hydroxide and sulfuric acid aqueous solutions with pH 1, 4, 7, 9, and 12 for 24 h, respectively. Then, the crystals were filtered, washed, and dried at room temperature. XRD analysis reveals that the host frameworks of 1 and 2 were retained after doping in the pH 1-12 aqueous solutions for 24 h, confirming that compounds 1 and 2 are stable in pH 1-12 aqueous solutions (). However, the block crystal of 1 became a powder when it was soaked in pH 12 aqueous solutions for 24 h, whereas compound 2 remained as dark black block crystals. These results confirm that the stability of 3D supramolecular framework was much enhanced when it was transferred into a covalent 3D framework.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of (a) 1 and (b) 2 for the as-synthesized samples and the samples soaked in pH 1–12 aqueous solution for 24 h.
elements.clean_text: 7  PXRD patterns of (a) 1 and (b) 2 for the as-synthesized samples and the samples soaked in pH 1-12 aqueous solution for 24 h.

elements.content: In summary, a 3D supramolecular framework consisting of metal–organic layers and typical Keggin-type POM pillars was designed and synthesized, which was successfully transferred into a covalent 3D MOF via extension of the length of POM pillars by capping a Keggin-type POM with V–O units. In the 2D metal–organic layer, the {Ni 12 } metal–organic crown acts as a functional unit to capture a [Ni­(H2O)2]2+ group with substitutable sites, which plays an important role in constructing the 3D supramolecular framework and the transformation of the 3D supramolecular framework into a covalent framework. Utilizing capping POMs as linking units to bridge 2D metal–organic layers with substitutable sites represents an efficient and promising method for constructing stable framework materials. Moreover, an electrocatalytic study reveals that compounds 1 and 2 can both act as bifunctional electrocatalysts toward the reduction of H2O2 and oxidation of NO2 –.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a 3D supramolecular framework consisting of metal-organic layers and typical Keggin-type POM pillars was designed and synthesized, which was successfully transferred into a covalent 3D MOF via extension of the length of POM pillars by capping a Keggin-type POM with V-O units. In the 2D metal-organic layer, the {Ni  12  } metal-organic crown acts as a functional unit to capture a [Ni(H2O)2]2+ group with substitutable sites, which plays an important role in constructing the 3D supramolecular framework and the transformation of the 3D supramolecular framework into a covalent framework. Utilizing capping POMs as linking units to bridge 2D metal-organic layers with substitutable sites represents an efficient and promising method for constructing stable framework materials. Moreover, an electrocatalytic study reveals that compounds 1 and 2 can both act as bifunctional electrocatalysts toward the reduction of H2O2 and oxidation of NO2 -.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.05 g, 0.43 mmol), Na2WO4·2H2O (0.2 g, 0.61 mmol), Ni­(Ac)2·4H2O (0.05 g, 0.20 mmol), triazole (0.033 g, 0.48 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of HCl (0.30 mL, 4.0 M) and H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After drying at room temperature, orange crystals were obtained with a yield of ca. 45% (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 1: W, 48.78; V, 1.13; Ni, 9.08. Found: W, 49.12; V, 0.98; Ni, 9.03. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν̃ 1623 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1163 (m), 1051 (m), 947 (s), 874 (s), 773 (s), 664 (s), 615 (s), 467 (s) cm–1.

Synthesis of <bold>2</bold>

A similar synthetic process of 1 was adopted for the synthesis of compound 2, except that l-tartaric acid (0.033 g, 0.22 mmol) was used in the synthesis of 2. Black crystals of 2 were isolated in ca. 36% yield (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 2: W, 40.69; V, 6.53; Ni, 9.57. Found: W, 39.74; V, 6.28; Ni, 10.32. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν̃ 1621 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1165 (m), 1081 (m), 948(s), 876 (s), 764 (s), 667 (s), 615(s), 490 (s) cm–1.

Synthesis of (Hbpy)<sub>4</sub>(VW<sub>12</sub>O<sub>40</sub>)·6H<sub>2</sub>O ({VW<sub>12</sub>}; bpy = 4,4′-Bipyridine)

A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.04 g, 0.33 mmol), Na2WO4·2H2O (0.1 g, 0.30 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.015 g, 0.01 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 170 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The brown crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After that, the crystals were dried at room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.05 g, 0.43 mmol), Na2WO4⋅2H2O (0.2 g, 0.61 mmol), Ni(Ac)2⋅4H2O (0.05 g, 0.20 mmol), triazole (0.033 g, 0.48 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of HCl (0.30 mL, 4.0 M) and H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After drying at room temperature, orange crystals were obtained with a yield of ca. 45% (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 1: W, 48.78; V, 1.13; Ni, 9.08. Found: W, 49.12; V, 0.98; Ni, 9.03. IR (KBr pellet) for 1: ν̃ 1623 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1163 (m), 1051 (m), 947 (s), 874 (s), 773 (s), 664 (s), 615 (s), 467 (s) cm-1.

Synthesis of 2 

A similar synthetic process of 1 was adopted for the synthesis of compound 2, except that l-tartaric acid (0.033 g, 0.22 mmol) was used in the synthesis of 2. Black crystals of 2 were isolated in ca. 36% yield (based on W). Anal. Calcd for 2: W, 40.69; V, 6.53; Ni, 9.57. Found: W, 39.74; V, 6.28; Ni, 10.32. IR (KBr pellet) for 2: ν̃ 1621 (m), 1508 (m), 1286 (m), 1165 (m), 1081 (m), 948(s), 876 (s), 764 (s), 667 (s), 615(s), 490 (s) cm-1.

Synthesis of (Hbpy)4(VW12O40)⋅6H2O ({VW12}; bpy = 4,4'-Bipyridine)

A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.04 g, 0.33 mmol), Na2WO4⋅2H2O (0.1 g, 0.30 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.015 g, 0.01 mmol), and distilled water (10 mL) was stirred for 30 min. After the addition of H3PO4 (0.10 mL, 7.5 M) to the reaction system, the mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 170 °C for 3 days and then was cooled to room temperature slowly at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The brown crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with distilled water. After that, the crystals were dried at room temperature.

Capped Polyoxometalate Pillars between Metal–Organic
Layers for Transferring a Supramolecular Structure into a Covalent
